body_html:
Digging a bit into the core code, It might be that the implementation of executor.cc is the problem:
The FrameState has an attribute called iterations, which is always resized to max_parallel_iterations:
define and resize.
Iterations is a gtl::inlined_vector which sets its internal storage when resized.
Iterations is only a vector of pointer, so 10**4 should not be a problem.

But maybe this provides a starting point for someone with a better overview of the internal of tf.
body_text:
Digging a bit into the core code, It might be that the implementation of executor.cc is the problem:
The FrameState has an attribute called iterations, which is always resized to max_parallel_iterations:
define and resize.
Iterations is a gtl::inlined_vector which sets its internal storage when resized.
Iterations is only a vector of pointer, so 10**4 should not be a problem.
But maybe this provides a starting point for someone with a better overview of the internal of tf.
body:
Digging a bit into the core code, It might be that the implementation of executor.cc is the problem:
The [FrameState](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/core/common_runtime/executor.cc#L935
) has an attribute called iterations, which is always resized to max_parallel_iterations:
[define](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/core/common_runtime/executor.cc#L1001) and [resize](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/core/common_runtime/executor.cc#L2310).
Iterations is a [gtl::inlined_vector](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/core/lib/gtl/inlined_vector.h#L330) which sets its internal storage when resized. 
Iterations is only a vector of pointer, so 10**4 should not be a problem. 

But maybe this provides a starting point for someone with a better overview of the internal of tf.
